maml:description.maml:para: Performs the appropriate installation activity on the file provided.
Install-PassiveInstallFile determines the appropriate action to take on the supplied file to install the file.
The Action to be taken depends on the file extension, and additional parameters to this cmdlet allow you to control the installation activity even more.
The file types currently supported are:
MSI - The msiexec.exe system command will be used to perform the installation using the /install option. If any arguments are provided, these will be added to the command line.
MSP - The msiexec.exe system command will be used to perform the installation update using the /update option. If any arguments are provided, these will be added to the command line.
EXE - The command will be directly run, using any arguments provided as command line arguments.

ZIP - The zip compressed file will be extracted under the directory specified as an argument to this cmdlet. If that folder does not currently exist it will be created. Password protected zip archives are not supported.
PS1 - The PowerShell file will be run in a new PowerShell session/window using the ByPass option.
BAT - The BAT file will be run using cmd.exe with the /c option, plus any arguments provided to this cmdlet.
CMD - The CMD file will be run using cmd.exe with the /c option, plus any arguments provided to this cmdlet.
REG - The REG file will be imported to the Windows Registry using the reg.exe program. Any arguments supplied are silently ignored.
Each of these actions create a new window to perform the installation. By default the window is visible, but the DoSilent flag will hide the window.
WhatIf and Confirm are supported.

maml:description.maml:para: Runs a visual timer for a given time with optional message.
Show-PassiveTimer will show a visual progress for the specified time in ms.
Think of this as a sleep with a progress bar. A progress bar is visually displayed and updated every 200ms until completion. You can specify an optional message for the display.

The user can pause the timer by selecting text anywhere in the PowerShell window, or hitting the P button on the keyboard. When paused, hitting the Q button will quite this sleep, while hitting any other key will resume the rest of the sleep.

The cmdlet uses a progress bar to show progress against the requested time. This progress bar is shown near the top of the PowerShell window, similar to other PS progress bars you've seen in the past. I recommend outputting a few blank lines (Write-Console "") at the top of your script so that this bar doesn't hide the important output messages that the user wants to review.
Total time in miliseconds for the timer.
